field_edited_text.value:
VIl. Concept Plans

.

*
L

#*
* 3
*



1. Pennsylvania Avenue Area

The Concept Plan alternates provided for the
reduction of existing retail floor space,
improved traffic circulation, substantially
increased parking facilities, improved pedestrian
circulation and an expanded role for the public
market.

Alternative methods of achieving the concept
plans were explored utilizing rehabilitation
methods. However, because of the extensive
dilapidation in the area, even a limited
rehabilitation program would not be
economically feasible and would not amount to
much more than a paint-up, fix-up, clean-up
effort.

A more attractive alternative would be the
creation of a Town Center through a major
renewal program. This could become one of the
most improtant projects undertaken by the
city, to demonstrate that a retail shopping core
of this kind can be revitalized. It could become
the cornerstone for all future redevelopment
efforts in this area.

The Town Center could be designed to provide
a broad range of community services and
facilities, including health; welfare and
education. In addition to up-to-date shopping
facilities with adequate parking facilities, it
could make available facilities for social,
cultural, and similar community activities for
various age groups. Provisions for business and
professional offices and for governmental
activities in the Town Center would increase
employment opportunities in the area.

Many of the facilities now in the trade area
could be consolidated into the Town Center,
freeing land for housing.

The Town Center could serve as a focal point
for services and facilities provided by the city
and other public agencies to residents in the
area. In developing it to serve a wide range of
activities, local citizens should be involved in
the initial planning phases so that the center is
designed to serve their needs.

2. Light Street Area
Concept plans were directed to consolidating
the retail core, increasing residential densities

around the retail core, improving traffic and
pedestrian circulation, improving the public
market and providing more off-street parking.

3. Monument Street Area

Concept plans specified reducing the retail floor
space in the area, improving traffic circulation
and parking, and providing a series of open
corridors and plazas, connected by pedestrian
ways. One important element was to shift the
geographic center of the retail core closer to the
Johns Hopkins Hospital. Another was to
increase residential densities in or near the
study area. In addition, ways of using the
public market area to greater advantage were
explored.

4. Feasibility of Rehabilitation

As part of the preliminary planning stage, the
cost of rehabilitating buildings in the three
study areas was studied, based on an analysis of
improvements carried out by merchants in the
previous five years. This information was
obtained from the merchants’ survey and the
building conditions’ survey.

Ninty-nine merchants reported spending
significant sums since 1961 on improvements to
premises they occupied. Using selected
examples, unit costs for rehabilitation were
developed, based on the condition of the
structure. Costs averaged between $1 per square
foot for correcting deficiencies in a building
rated as standard and $12 a square foot for a
substandard building. Where storefront
modernization took place, the unit cost was
even higher.

Cost estimates were applied to 12 buildings in
each area. |t was assumed that rehabilitation
efforts would be confined to the first floor,
that the front facade would be renovated and
that the building would be used for retailing.
Estimated costs were applied uniformly to all
buildings regardless of the existing state of
storefront modernization. This was done to
provide a uniform base to determine whether a
reasonable range of costs could be arrived at for
the level of rehabilitation anticipated in the
Improvement program.
